Department of Biological Sciences and NERC Centre for Population Biology,  Imperial College London, Silwood Park campus, Ascot, Berkshire, SL5 7PY United Kingdom   tel: +44 207 59 42 222   fax: +44 207 59 42 339  email: c.mazancourt@imperial.ac.uk   2  Laboratoire d’Ecologie, UMR 7625, Ecole Normale Supérieure, 46, rue d’Ulm, F-75230 Paris Cedex   05, France   tel: +33 1 44 32 37 09   fax: +33 1 44 32 38 85   email: loreau@ens.fr   3  Adaptive Dynamics Network, International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, A-2361   Laxenburg, Austria   tel: +43 2236 807 386   fax: +43 2236 71313   email: dieckmann@iiasa.ac.at   Running title: mutualism and adaptation   Type of article: Essay review in Journal of Ecology   de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann           2    Summary 1  1- A mutualism is a mutually beneficial interaction between individuals of two  2  species. Using the ongoing debate about plant-herbivore interactions as a springboard, 3  we show that different measures of benefit arise depending on whether adaptation 4  within the mutualism is considered. 5  2- A species’ proximate response measures the short-term effect of addition or 6  removal of the partner species, without allowing for any adaptation. We define a 7  proximate mutualism as an interaction in which removal of each partner results in a 8  decreased performance of the other, i.e., both species show a positive proximate 9  response to the presence of the partner. 10  3- Almost all empirical studies use the proximate response criterion. However, a 11  proximate mutualism might only reflect evolved dependence (implying that, through  12  adaptation to the partner, a species has lost its ability to perform well without the 13  partner). Therefore, some authors discard the proximate definition of mutualism, to 14  prefer what we define as ultimate mutualism. 15  4- A species’ ultimate response measures the long-term effect of adding or 16  removing the partner species, thus allowing for the focal species to adapt to the 17  absence or presence of its partner. We define an ultimate mutualism as an interaction 18  in which each partner could never have performed as well without the other, even if it 19  was adapted to the absence of the partner. In other words, a mutualism is called 20  ultimate if both species show a positive ultimate response to the presence of the 21  partner. Despite the conceptual attractiveness of this definition, ultimate responses are 22  difficult to measure, rendering the notion of ultimate mutualism operationally 23  problematic. 24  5- Using examples from the literature, we demonstrate the counterintuitive result 25  that even obligate mutualisms are not necessarily ultimate mutualisms.  26  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann           3    6- Finally, we define mutualistic evolution as evolution of a trait that is costly to 1  the bearer but beneficial to its partner in a proximate mutualism and show that,  2  paradoxically, neither proximate nor ultimate mutualisms necessarily result in  3  mutualistic evolution.  4  7- We conclude that the proximate response is the only criterion for mutualism that 5  is operational in empirical research. A possible key mechanism that can generate a 6  benefit in such mutualisms, evolved dependence, has to be further investigated 7  empirically and seriously taken into account in theoretical studies, if our  8  understanding of mutualism is to evolve.  9  8- More than a semantic case of hair splitting, our paper reveals a naive view of  10  mutualism that needs revision. We need to recognise that in most if not all 11  interactions now considered as mutualisms, measured benefits to at least one partner 12  are likely to be partly or even completely the result of adaptation to the partner, 13  leading to evolved dependence, rather than to what we would like to consider as 14  “real” or ultimate benefits.  15   16  Keywords: adaptation, coevolution, evolved dependence, mutualism,  17  overcompensation, plant-herbivore interaction, proximate response, ultimate 18  responseisms.  19  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann                                                                                                  4   Introduction 1  Mutualisms are widespread in nature (Boucher et al., 1982; Bronstein, 1994b; 2  Menge, 2000; Richardson et al., 2000; Stachowicz, 2001). Although about a quarter of 3  ecological studies are devoted to mutualism (Bronstein, 1994b), our understanding of 4  and theoretical insights into this type of interaction are limited (Bronstein, 1994b). 5  One factor that might critically contribute to this gap is an ambiguity in the concept of 6  mutualism when there is, as is usual in a mutualistic interaction, adaptation to the 7  partner species. Here we focus on an interaction in a given environment and ask how 8  to determine whether or not it is mutualistic; of course, the same interaction might be 9  classified differently in a different environment (conditional mutualism; see Box 1 10  and Bronstein, 1994a). 11  We would like to start with a short example to set the scene for our argument. Jeon 12  (1972) witnessed the emergence of an obligate mutualism in the lab, evolving all the 13  way from parasitism. Amoeba discoides was infected with bacteria that initially 14  caused heavy mortality, small size, slow growth, and slow clone formation, and a high 15  sensitivity to adverse conditions. The amoeba and the bacteria coevolved, and after 5 16  years of infection, the adverse effects of the bacteria had disappeared. Moreover, after 17  this coevolution, neither the amoebae nor the bacteria would survive without the 18  other. This interaction is thus a clear example of a mutualism: since both organisms 19  need their partner to survive, they clearly derive a benefit from their partner’s 20  presence. However, is it possible that the amoeba would have been better off had the 21  bacteria never been there? Does the bacterium provide a “real” benefit to the amoeba? 22  Hence, should this interaction really be viewed as a mutualism? 23  In the following sections, we explain and define different criteria used to test for 24  mutualism: proximate response, ultimate response, and mutualistic evolution. We 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann                                                                                                  5   show that there is a conflict between what is actually measured when testing for 1  mutualism, resulting in what we call proximate mutualism, and what many of us 2  would like a mutualism to mean, resulting in what we call ultimate mutualism. Each 3  criterion presented here has been used previously by a number of different authors – 4  yet these criteria have never been named, clearly defined, and properly contrasted. 5  Filling this lacuna provides the platform for a thought-provoking discussion about 6  what mutualism means. Several counterintuitive results will be demonstrated along 7  the way. 8  This study is motivated by a debate about plant-herbivore interactions. Some plants 9  have been shown to overcompensate, in the sense that their fitness was increased by 10  herbivore damage. The controversy in the literature that ensued from this observation 11  tried to clarify whether such a result implies that these plants actually benefit from 12  herbivory, so that the plant–herbivore interaction would have to be considered 13  mutualistic. After a general presentation of the ideas underlying this debate, we 14  discuss specific applications as well as their broader implication for other systems. 15  We suggest that effects like overcompensation should be taken as valid evidence that 16  herbivory benefits plants. However, the mechanism that is likely to generate this 17  benefit, evolved dependence, requires to be further investigated empirically and to be 18  seriously taken into account in empirical and theoretical studies, if our understanding 19  of mutualism is to evolve. 20  All key technical terms introduced in this study are defined in Box 1. 21    de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann                                                                                                  6   I. Theoretical basis 1  Proximate mutualism 2  Definition of proximate mutualism 3  One classical approach to test for mutualism experimentally is to evaluate the 4  performance of a species before and after its partner has been removed, or has been 5  kept at low density (Bender et al., 1984; Krebs, 1985; Schoener, 1983). This 6  comparison defines what we call the proximate response of a species to the removal 7  of its partner, and is the defining criterion for a proximate mutualism (Figure 1 and 8  Box 1). It is important to stress that, in this definition, the performance of the same 9  genotype (or group thereof) is compared with and without the partner species. The 10  proximate response might depend on the genotype considered, and, notably, on its 11  status of adaptation to the partner (Figure 1). 12  The proximate response criterion is used in most empirical studies of mutualisms. 13  Bronstein (1994b), reviewing the underlying experiments, described them as follows: 14  “mutualists were excluded or added… For example, many pollination studies 15  examined plant success after all but a single visitor species were excluded (Herrera, 16  1987)… Nearly all experimental studies of plant-ant protector mutualisms involved 17  excluding the ants in order to measure their benefit to the plant (Koptur & Lawton, 18  1988; Smiley, 1986).” Also mutualistic or parasitic effects of mycorrhizal associations 19  or of leaf endophytes have been assessed by comparing plant proximate response, i.e., 20  the performance of a plant genotype or population with and without these partners 21  (Faeth & Sullivan, 2003; Klironomos, 2003). 22  Proximate mutualism can result from evolved dependence 23  However, an observed decrease of performance when a focal species’ partner is 24  removed might result from the fact that the focal species was adapted to the presence 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann                                                                                                  7   of its partner, and had thus compromised its ability to perform well in the partner’s 1  absence. In the context of endosymbioses, such an effect has been called evolved 2  dependence (Douglas & Smith, 1989). 3  It is important to emphasize that evolved dependence can occur independently of 4  whether or not an association is obligate; it is likely to happen in any type of 5  association where there is adaptation. Evolved dependence is in principle quantifiable 6  as the performance difference between the genotype that is adapted to the partner’s 7  absence and the genotype that is adapted to its presence, both measured in the absence 8  of the partner (Figure 1, Box 1). It comprises the cost of traits evolving as an 9  adaptation to the partner’s presence, as well as the “cost” of having lost some traits 10  that were adaptive in the absence of the partner (the latter cost appears in quotes 11  because it only is a cost when the partner is removed). Operationally, a very rough 12  indicator of the expected degree of mutual adaptation is the length of time that 13  partners have been in ecological contact with each other or, alternatively, the length of 14  time these partners have been separated. 15  In conclusion, the proximate response of a genotype is bound to depend on its 16  status of adaptation to the partner. A low performance when the partner is removed 17  can occur simply because the genotype is not adapted to this situation: its low 18  performance stems from evolved dependence. This is not the type of “real benefit” we 19  have in mind when assessing a mutualistic interaction. 20  Ultimate mutualism 21  Definition of ultimate mutualism 22  To understand whether evolved dependence is responsible for an observed 23  proximate mutualism between two species, or whether, instead, there is a “real 24  benefit” from the interaction, it is important to introduce a second criterion for 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann                                                                                                  8    mutualism. Here we have to ask whether the focal species performs better than it 1  would ever have without the other species. We thus have to consider the ultimate 2  response of a species to its partner, measured by comparing the performance of two 3  different genotypes (or groups thereof): the performance of the one genotype adapted 4  to the partner, in the partner’s presence, is compared to the performance of the other 5  genotype adapted to the absence of the partner, in the partner’s absence. This 6  criterion, of course, is not without practical difficulties, which we will discuss in 7  detail below. The criterion leads to defining an ultimate mutualism as an interaction in 8  which each partner shows a positive ultimate response to the presence of the other 9  (Figure 1, Box 1). 10  The proximate response of a population adapted to its partner is equal to its 11  ultimate response plus evolved dependence. Therefore, if a population derives an 12  ultimate benefit from a partner species, it is also likely to derive a proximate benefit 13  from this interaction. However, the reverse is not true: a population adapted to the 14  partner that shows a proximate benefit from the interaction might derive no ultimate 15  benefit from the association whatsoever, if evolved dependence is the only cause of 16  the proximate benefit. 17  The existence of evolved dependence is one reason for discrepancies between 18  proximate and ultimate responses. Dependence of this sort is likely to be important 19  for partners with a long history of coevolution, and we must thus expect some such 20  interactions to be proximate but not ultimate mutualisms. 21  Accounting for ultimate responses in the literature 22  In studies of mutualism, a few authors adopted the ultimate response to measure 23  the benefit of an interaction. Examples from the plant-herbivore literature are 24  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    9 described below in the sections “Theoretical argument for plant’s ultimate benefit” 1  and “Measurement of plant’s ultimate responses”. 2  Another example of an author defining mutualism based on ultimate responses is 3  Roughgarden (1975) in a model for the evolution of a symbiosis between fish and 4  anemones. Assuming the ancestral state of fish to be free-living, Roughgarden 5  assessed the benefit of the symbiosis as the difference between the fitness of the free-6  living genotype and the fitness of the symbiotic genotype with an anemone. The 7  model assumes a strong evolved dependence in the system: when the symbiotic 8  genotype cannot find a host anemone, or when its host anemone dies, its reproductive 9  output is much reduced. 10  Measurement of ultimate responses 11  Measuring ultimate responses requires tests both on a genotype that is adapted to 12  the presence of the partner and on a genotype that is adapted to the absence of the 13  partner. Since there is no point in defining quantities that are not measurable in 14  practice, the status of adaptation to the partner must be assessed pragmatically. In 15  particular cases, it would be impossible to assess whether adaptation had reached an 16  evolutionary endpoint; these might not even exist (Dieckmann et al., 1995; 17  Gomulkiewicz et al., 2000; Thompson & Cunningham, 2002). However, this should 18  not prevent evaluation of an ultimate response based on the current status of 19  adaptation, which can be very roughly assessed based on the length of coevolutionary 20  history experienced by the partners. Note that in this context the strength of selection 21  imposed by a species on its partner is likely to be more important that the length of 22  their coevolutionary history, and would be a better proxy to the status of adaptation if 23  it could be quantified. For assessing ultimate responses, four cases can be 24  distinguished: 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    10 • We may have access to an ancestral state that is not adapted to the partner. 1  Performance measurements for the two genotypes under the appropriate 2  conditions can then be undertaken. 3  • The organism is fast evolving and viable without the partner, so that 4  experimental adaptation to the partner’s absence can be selected for on a 5  feasible timescale. Performance differences can then be measured as in the 6  first case. Unfortunately, the population experimentally adapted to the 7  partner’s absence might also inadvertently be subjected to other selective 8  pressures, besides those arising from the partner’s absence. 9  • Even though there may be no access to a suitable ancestral state, there may yet 10  exist separate populations of the focal organism with histories of evolution 11  with and without the partner. Measurements can then be carried out comparing 12  such populations, provided that sufficient replicates exist. This is not as 13  satisfactory a situation as in the preceding cases, because other factors are 14  likely to co-vary with the partner’s presence or absence. 15  • There may be no access to an ancestral state, the organism may not be viable 16  without the partner, or, even if it is viable, its generation time may be too long 17  for experimental adaptation to the partner’s absence to be feasible. Ultimate 18  responses then cannot be measured. However, if there is sufficient genetic 19  variation in the species, it may still be possible to search for genetic trade-offs 20  between the focal species’ performance with and without the partner to 21  establish indirect evidence for evolved dependence. 22  Douglas and Smith (1989) discuss in detail the difficulties of measuring ultimate 23  responses in endosymbioses. 24  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    11 To summarize, the concept of ultimate mutualism is very satisfactory conceptually, 1  but in many cases might prove unrealistic in terms of measurements. Unfortunately, 2  some authors seem to accept only this definition of mutualism and discard any 3  alternative based on proximate responses, thus apparently overlooking the difficulties 4  of measuring ultimate responses as well as the fact that most empirical work has only 5  measured proximate responses. 6  An obligate mutualism is not necessarily an ultimate mutualism 7  We would like to draw attention to the slightly counterintuitive fact that an obligate 8  mutualism is not necessarily an ultimate mutualism. We presented the case described 9  by Jeon (1972) in the introduction. Amoeba discoides was infected with a parasitic 10  bacterium. After adaptation took place, the adverse effects of the bacteria had 11  disappeared, suggesting a neutral ultimate response of the amoebae to the bacteria. 12  Moreover, both organisms had become dependent on the other for survival, resulting 13  in a mutualism that was both proximate and obligate. Importantly, however, the 14  proximate benefit derived by the amoeba from the interaction was probably due to 15  evolved dependence: the amoeba lost traits that made it adapted to the absence of the 16  bacteria, and there is no evidence for the interaction providing an ultimate benefit to 17  the amoeba. 18  Other examples involves Wolbachia, intracellular bacteria infecting a number of 19  invertebrates. In arthropods, these bacteria are rarely found to be beneficial to their 20  hosts and thus provide a striking example of selfish cytoplasmic elements. Despite 21  physiological costs or even virulence, they are able to maintain themselves through 22  induced modifications to host reproductive biology. Dedeine et al. (2001) report a 23  case of obligate mutualism with the parasitoid wasp Asobara tabida Nees 24  (Hymenoptera, Braconidae). Female wasps could not reproduce after removal of 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    12 Wolbachia because they could not produce mature oocytes. Dedeine et al. (2001) 1  suggest that the wasp or its ancestor became associated with a Wolbachia that already 2  produced a factor necessary for wasp oogenesis. The host then lost the capacity to 3  produce this costly factor itself, thus becoming totally dependent on the bacteria for 4  reproduction. Similar losses of function have been reported in other insect-Wolbachia 5  interactions. For example, there are several cases in which parthenogenesis induction 6  by Wolbachia infection can be reversed by curing the infection (Stouthamer, 1997), 7  but in some cases the host species can no longer function successfully as a sexual 8  taxon due to adverse changes in male and/or female traits (Arakaki et al., 2001; 9  Gottlieb & Zchori-Fein, 2001; Hunter, 1999). Gottlieb and Zchori-Fein (2001) argue 10  that since sexual reproduction has ceased, selection on sexual traits has been removed, 11  leading to the disappearance of or reduction in these traits. They suggest that in 12  symbionts that manipulate their host’s reproduction to induce parthenogenesis, the 13  host is being captured by the bacteria for the latter’s transmission benefit, leaving no 14  other way of reproduction for the host. These cases are clear examples of obligate 15  proximate mutualisms, where the main benefits for the host come from evolved 16  dependence. We suggest that these interactions are unlikely to be ultimate 17  mutualisms, but this has not yet been tested. 18  Even for interactions that went through a phase of ultimate mutualism it is 19  plausible that the interaction’s ultimate costs escalate over evolutionary time. Such a 20  development is especially likely for species that evolve an extreme dependence on 21  their partner, and therefore cannot get out of an interaction even if its costs escalate 22  (Pellmyr et al., 1997). As ultimate costs grow, the obligate interaction is likely to 23  cease to be an ultimate mutualism. For example, Johnson et al. (1997) argue that 24  plants that are highly dependent on mycorrhizae for nutrient uptake might have a 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    13 greater risk of mycorrhizal parasitism in highly fertilized systems, because they might 1  not closely control “unnecessary” root growth or rate of colonisation. It is possible 2  that a plant in an obligate mycorrhizal association might be “trapped” in this obligate 3  interaction even when conditions change and the interaction no longer implies any 4  ultimate benefit. 5  Questions resulting from comparing proximate and ultimate responses in mutualism 6  research 7  So far, in empirical studies, measured costs and benefits are almost exclusively 8  proximate (i.e., the same group of genotypes was compared with and without the 9  partner; Bronstein, 1994b). New and interesting research directions could thus be 10  opened up by investigating ultimate costs and benefits where possible, and by looking 11  for genetic trade-offs between genotypes differentially adapted to a partner’s absence 12  and presence. 13  A very important question in mutualism research is the evolution and maintenance 14  of mutualisms in the presence of cheaters (Bronstein, 2001; Denison et al., 2003; 15  Ferriere et al., 2002; Freckleton & Cote, 2003; Hoeksema & Kummel, 2003; 16  Johnstone & Bshary, 2002; Law et al., 2001; Yu, 2001). Measuring the costs induced 17  by the presence of cheaters is essential to tackle this question, and contrasting 18  proximate and ultimate costs might thus be a key element in advancing this line of 19  research. For example, nectar robbers damage floral parts and take resources without 20  effecting pollination (Inouye, 1980). Most removal experiments assess the cost of 21  robbers on the female fitness of the plant by experimentally removing robbers, thus 22  assessing the proximate cost of robbers’ presence. However, robbers also induce an 23  ultimate cost that is likely to be higher than the proximate cost. Roubik et al. (1985) 24  showed that the flowers of a tropical forest understory treelet, Quassia amara, had 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    14 lower corolla length and nectar production on an island where nectar robbers were 1  absent. This suggests that without robbers, there is selection against these traits, so 2  that the performance of plants adapted to robbers is suboptimal. Accordingly, evolved 3  dependence enlarges the ultimate cost of robbers’ presence relative to the 4  corresponding proximate cost. Measuring the evolved dependence for this system 5  would involve comparing the performances of different plant genotypes in the 6  presence and absence of robbers, in order to establish whether these plants show 7  variation in their adaptation to the presence of cheaters. 8  Evolution in a mutualism 9  We now examine a third dimension according to which mutualisms can be 10  assessed: the concept of mutualistic evolution is key to many discussions about 11  mutualism. We define mutualistic evolution as evolution of investment in the partner. 12  Such an adaptation has a direct cost to the bearer, but, other things being equal, 13  increases the performance of both partners. It is important to realize that not all 14  adaptations to a mutualistic partner qualify as mutualistic evolution. This is because 15  traits may also evolve to allow better exploitation of the partner or to prevent better 16  exploitation by the partner; in addition, certain functions may be lost evolutionarily if 17  they are provided more efficiently by the partner (Connor, 1995). 18  Where does the benefit of an interaction come from? 19  For defining proximate and ultimate mutualism above, we used criteria based on 20  the net effect of the presence of the partner (an effect-based definition; Abrams, 21  1987), rather than descriptions of the physiological and ecological processes through 22  which benefits are gained (a process-based definition; Abrams, 1987). For defining 23  mutualistic evolution it is interesting to distinguish between different categories of 24  benefit gained from an interaction. Connor (1995) classifies the benefits derived from 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    15 an interaction as (a) by-product benefits, occurring incidentally at no cost to the donor 1  (as for two plants accidentally growing together with one taking advantage of the 2  other’s protective thorns). Connor contrasts this with (b) purloined benefits, obtained 3  by exploiting the partner (as a predator would), and (c) invested benefits, obtained 4  despite a direct cost because the partner is giving something for a return. 5  Proximate and ultimate mutualisms can result from benefits of any of these types. 6  Several authors, however, have demanded evidence of evolution of invested benefits 7  as demonstration that an interaction is “truly” mutualistic (Belsky et al., 1993; 8  Agrawal, 2000). Below we argue that such evolution does not necessarily happen 9  either in a proximate or in an ultimate mutualism, and that it can occur even towards 10  an exploitative partner. We describe scenarios that would lead to such counterintuitive 11  results, by considering simple cases of two interacting species coevolving in a 12  constant environment. We note that since coevolution is often diffuse (Agrawal & 13  Van Zandt, 2003; Inouye & Stinchcombe, 2001), theory taking into account this 14  complexity needs to be developed (Loreau et al., 2003; Stanton, 2003) – but this 15  cannot be the purpose of our present study. 16  Antagonistic strategies can be selected for in mutualistic interactions 17  A mutualistic strategy might be counter-selected in a proximate or ultimate 18  mutualism. This is because investment in the partner is not selected for if the benefit 19  of the interaction has to be shared with too many conspecifics, illustrating the well-20  known fact that evolution of investment in the partner requires that “the partner must 21  reciprocate and that the reciprocated benefit must be captured by the initial giver or its 22  offspring” (Yu, 2001). Thus, a trait will not evolve if its beneficial effect is uniformly 23  distributed over all conspecifics. A case in point is the evolution of fruit abortion in 24  senita cacti or yuccas as a means of decreasing seed predation by their respective 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    16 pollinators: such adaptations will only occur if the pollinator population is localized 1  on the individual plant (Holland & DeAngelis, 2002). If the benefit of an investment 2  in the partner is distributed over conspecifics, there might even be selection for an 3  antagonistic strategy, as we show below in a plant-herbivore example. 4  Selection can favour investment into an exploiting partner 5  A possible scenario involves evolution of a trait that benefits the bearer by 6  protecting it against predation. For example, the majority of the estimated 6000 7  species of Lycaenids have associations with ants that range from mutualism to 8  parasitism (Pierce et al., 2002). A standard interpretation of the mutualistic 9  association is that lycaenid larvae produce secretions in order to attract ants and 10  benefit from their protection from parasitoids. However, another interpretation is 11  possible: Malicky (1970) has suggested that lycaenid larvae might produce secretions 12  in order to prevent predation by ants. These secretions would then be an example of 13  an investment into an exploiting partner. 14   15  II. Plant-herbivore interactions 16  Plant proximate response to herbivore removal 17  Experimental studies have demonstrated that, under some conditions, herbivory 18  leads to increased plant fitness. Lifetime reproductive output (seed production of 19  monocarpic plant species, controlling for seed weight and germination potential) was 20  increased by grazing or cutting for some populations of Ipomopsis aggregata 21  (Gronemeyer et al., 1997; Paige, 1992; Paige & Whitham, 1987) and Gentianella 22  campestris (Huhta et al., 2000b; Juenger et al., 2000; Lennartsson et al., 1997, 1998). 23  Other monocarpic species can show increased seed production following moderate 24  cutting under field conditions (Huhta et al., 2003) or artificial conditions such as 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    17 reduced competitive pressure and/or fertilizer application (Alward & Joern, 1993; 1  Benner, 1988; Huhta et al., 2000a). The results on Ipomopsis aggregata and 2  Gentianella campestris thus suggest that a proximate mutualism can exist between 3  these plants and their herbivores. 4  Some authors (Agrawal, 2000; Vail, 1994) accept this evidence as confirmation of 5  a possible benefit of the plant from herbivory, leading to the claim that plant-6  herbivore mutualism may exist. 7  Evolved dependence of plants towards their herbivores 8  Increased seed production in overcompensating plants results from the release of 9  apical dominance and from the production of numerous tillers (Benner, 1988; Huhta 10  et al., 2000b; Juenger et al., 2000; Lennartsson et al., 1997, 1998; Paige, 1999; Paige 11  & Whitham, 1987; Strauss & Agrawal, 1999). If the probability of herbivory is high, a 12  plant that produces multiple shoots from the beginning of the season will lose them all 13  to the herbivore (Crawley, 1987). If, however, herbivory only occurs during a short 14  period, damage by herbivores can serve as a signal for the plant that the risk of 15  herbivory soon will be over, and post-herbivory activation of dormant meristems is 16  selected for (Tuomi et al., 1994b; Vail, 1992). Several models suggest that plants 17  adapted to herbivory should have developed mechanisms for resource mobilization 18  triggered by herbivory (Jaremo et al., 1999; Lehtila, 2000; Mathews, 1994; Nilsson et 19  al., 1996a, 1996b; Simons & Johnston, 1999; Tuomi et al., 1994b; Vail, 1992, 1994). 20  This adaptation leads to low reproduction in the absence of herbivory, just because 21  this plant genotype is not adapted to a situation without herbivores, and there is a 22  trade-off between the ability of a plant to perform with and without herbivores. In the 23  presence of herbivores, it is advantageous to wait before allocating resources to 24  growth. In the absence of herbivores, however, this trait is disadvantageous and plants 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    18 should instead allocate all their resources to growth as soon as possible. Mechanisms 1  like this might explain the proximate benefit that these plants derive from herbivores. 2  Evolved dependence has likely arisen in many plant-herbivore interactions. In 3  Gentianella campestris, the plant’s ability to produce more seeds after herbivore 4  damage only occurs in populations adapted to either herbivory or mowing 5  (Lennartsson et al., 1997, 1998). Similarly, the ability to tolerate herbivory was 6  negatively correlated with fitness in the absence of herbivory in Ipomoea purpurea 7  (Tiffin & Rausher, 1999). 8  Because overcompensation is likely to result from evolved dependence rather than 9  any other mechanism of “real” benefit, some authors do not accept the proximate 10  response of overcompensation as sufficient proof that plants might benefit from 11  herbivory (Belsky et al., 1993; Järemo et al., 1999; Mathews, 1994; Tuomi et al., 12  1994b). 13  Ultimate mutualism in plant-herbivore interactions 14  Theoretical arguments for plant-herbivore interactions causing an ultimate cost to 15  plants 16  Vail (1992) built a model showing that plants benefit from herbivory because 17  plants adapted to herbivores should perform best with herbivores. However, he noted 18  that although removal of herbivores reduces fitness in the short term, “that would 19  simultaneously impart a selective pressure… and thus raise fitness in the long run.” 20  Mathews (1994) criticized Vail’s interpretation: “although Vail speculates about the 21  benefits of herbivory, his model in fact contradicts him because plant fitness is higher 22  in the absence of herbivory than anywhere else.” For Mathews, the proximate 23  criterion is not valid for testing benefits from herbivory: there needs to be an ultimate 24  benefit resulting from the presence of herbivores. Also in other recent studies there 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann                                                                                                   19   seems to be some convergence towards using the ultimate response criterion (Järemo 1  et al., 1999; Nilsson et al., 1996a, 1996b; Simons & Johnston, 1999; Stowe et al., 2  2000; Tuomi et al., 1994a, 1994b), and rejecting the validity of a proximal response 3  criterion. 4  No empirical evidence for plant-herbivore interactions causing an ultimate benefit for 5  plants 6  Järemo et al. (1999) measured the ultimate response of Gentianella campestris to 7  herbivore removal. Based on existing data, they compared populations that have 8  evolved with the herbivore to populations that have evolved without it. They found no 9  empirical evidence for an ultimate benefit for the plant, but there was also no evidence 10  for an ultimate cost. 11  In a different study, the comparison of reaction norms of maternal lines of 12  Gentianella campestris from different populations also failed to show any trade-off 13  between fitness in the absence of herbivory and the ability to compensate for 14  herbivory (Juenger et al., 2000). To conclude, this plant seems to show no strong 15  ultimate response to herbivores: herbivores seem ultimately neutral. 16  Mutualistic evolution in plant-herbivore interactions 17  Belsky et al. (1993) define a “mutualistic plant” as a plant that “makes some 18  portion of their bodies available to herbivores” (i.e., a plant that invests in the 19  herbivore), whereas an “antagonistic plant” defends itself against herbivores. They 20  argue that if the plant-herbivore interaction was a mutualism, then we should witness 21  the evolution of mutualistic plants, implying mutualistic evolution through which a 22  plant evolves to invest in its herbivore. However, here we argue that this is not 23  necessarily the case. 24  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    20 If herbivores have a positive effect on plant fitness through the efficient recycling 1  of nutrients (de Mazancourt et al., 2001), then plants receive a benefit from the 2  presence of herbivores. The more efficient the herbivore is at recycling nutrients, the 3  more benefit there is to the plant, and at high herbivore recycling efficiencies the 4  interaction can well be a proximate or even an ultimate mutualism. However, when 5  nutrient cycling is redistributed amongst all plants, mutualistic plants experience a 6  direct cost and exert a positive effect on the herbivore. They do not receive a one-on-7  one benefit, as all plants receive a benefit through the herbivore. It can be shown that 8  the more efficient the herbivore becomes at recycling nutrients, the more selection 9  favours defended plants, because they benefit more from nutrients recycled from less 10  defended plants. Therefore, the more herbivores recycle, the more antagonistic plant 11  strategies are selected for and plant defences thus go up. At the same time, 12  nevertheless, the interaction can become a proximate and even an ultimate mutualism, 13  as long as herbivores conserve nutrients in the system to and extent that enables plants 14  to perform better on the whole. 15  Although there have been many empirical studies on the effects of herbivores on 16  nutrient cycling (Carpenter & Kitchell, 1984; Chaneton et al., 1996; Detling, 1988; 17  Floate, 1981; Jarvis et al., 1989; Pastor & Cohen, 1997; Ritchie et al., 1998; Ruess et 18  al., 1989; Ruess & McNaughton, 1988; Seagle et al., 1992; Wilson & Jefferies, 1996), 19  none has yet studied the net effect of herbivory on plant fitness and the resultant 20  selection pressure on plants. Therefore there exists no empirical indication to date that 21  would allow us to assess how widely the scenario sketched here occurs in nature. 22    de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    21 Conclusions 1  So, what is a mutualism when there is adaptation to the partner? In this paper we 2  have defined and systematically contrasted three alternative definitions of mutualism. 3  If we need to choose only one of them, it has to be that of proximate mutualism. If we 4  were to discard the criterion of proximate mutualism, we would abandon core 5  evidence for most studied examples of mutualism. However, in choosing this 6  criterion, we must acknowledge the potential importance of evolved dependence as a 7  valid mechanism that creates a benefit resulting from the partner’s presence. In the 8  plant-herbivore debate, this means that we have to accept evidence of 9  overcompensation as evidence that plants indeed benefit from herbivory (provided 10  that overcompensation occurs as a result of a realistic herbivory event), however 11  irritating and counterintuitive this might be. More empirical and theoretical studies 12  should take into account evolved dependence as a possibly crucial mechanism 13  generating mutualism. 14  Ultimate mutualism is similar to what many people would intuitively like to call 15  mutualism, or “true” mutualism (as stated by Agrawal 2000; i.e., a mutualism that 16  does not stem from evolved dependence). Unfortunately, the ultimate response is not 17  even meaningful in many classical examples of mutualism. Also because of major 18  difficulties involved in its measurement, we believe that the ultimate response will 19  remain an abstraction that is not always useful. Moreover, even obligate mutualisms 20  are not guaranteed to be “true” or ultimate mutualisms. 21  The plant-herbivore controversy seemed resolved by adopting a criterion of 22  ultimate rather than proximate benefit (Järemo et al., 1999), thus rejecting the 23  proximate criterion of overcompensation. We contend that this is not satisfactory, as 24  the proximate criterion cannot be rejected without serious reconsideration of most 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    22 classical examples of mutualism. Instead, we argue, we ought to recognise the 1  potentially very important role of evolved dependence in all mutualisms. 2  Finally, the analysis of adaptations that can bring about, maintain, or jeopardize 3  mutualistic interactions needs to be disentangled from the criteria for mutualism itself. 4  As we have shown, traits that favour or harm a partner might evolve in any type of 5  interaction: hence, defining mutualism through mutualistic evolution seems of limited 6  utility. 7  Differentiating between the three concepts introduced here allows us to focus on 8  new and stimulating research questions. For many interactions that are considered 9  mutualistic it will be illuminating to evaluate empirically (a) whether there is 10  adaptation to the presence of the partner, (b) through which route evolved dependence 11  has been selected for, (c) how evolved dependence contributes to proximate benefits, 12  and (d) how proximate and ultimate benefits affect the mutualistic or antagonistic 13  evolution of traits. 14   15  Acknowledgements 16  We thank Tim Barraclough, Martin Bidartondo, Judie Bronstein, Austin Burt, 17  James Cook, Angela Douglas, Jaboury Ghazoul, David Gibson, Matt Goddard, 18  Edward Allen Herre, Jason Hoeksema, Mark Rees, Mark Schwartz, Juha Tuomi, 19  Stephen Vail, Andrew Wilby, Doug Yu, and several anonymous reviewers for useful 20  discussions and comments on previous versions of this manuscript. Biological Journal of the Linnean Society, 24  72, 529-546. 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    33 Box 1: Definition of key terms 1  Performance: To compare the performance of organisms under different conditions 2  (with or without partners), an absolute measure of performance is required, rather than 3  a relative one. What measure to use is not a trivial question. Possible performance 4  measures include the following. (1) Absolute fitness of an individual, i.e., its lifetime 5  reproductive success, always equals 1 when populations are at steady state, so that 6  care must be taken in setting the conditions under which lifetime reproductive success 7  is measured (as described below). Proxies of absolute fitness can sometime be used. 8  (2) Short-term population growth rate is a good proxy of lifetime reproductive 9  success under conditions of repeated disturbance, through which a population mostly 10  remains in an exponential growth phase. (3) Long-term population size may be a 11  proxy of absolute fitness for populations close to steady state. Discrepancies between 12  the different measures are discussed in Abrams (1987) and van Baalen and Jansen 13  (2001). 14  Proximate response: Difference in performance of a genotype (or group thereof) 15  before and after short-term removal (or addition) of the partner species. Note that the 16  performance of the same genotype (or group thereof) is thus compared under two 17  conditions, one of which it might not be adapted to. Measurement – If performance is 18  measured as lifetime reproductive success, the focal species’ density after removal 19  must be kept at its value before removal. We can then consider the focal population 20  with its partner, with LRS = 1, remove the partner, and measure the new lifetime 21  reproductive success, LRSP. The proximate response to removal is LRSP – 1. 22  Proximate mutualism: Interspecific interaction in which removal of each partner 23  results in a decreased performance of the other. It is characterised by negative 24  proximate responses of each species to the removal of the other species. Such 25  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    34 negative proximate responses can be due to “real” or ultimate benefits, but 1  alternatively may merely reflect evolved dependence resulting from adaptation to 2  partner. 3  Evolved dependence: Through adaptation to the presence of an interacting partner 4  species, a population might lose its ability to perform well in the absence of such a 5  partner. Evolved dependence measures the loss of performance of a focal population 6  in the absence of a partner due to its adaptation to the presence of the partner. 7  Measurement – If performance is measured as lifetime reproductive success, we can 8  consider the focal population with its partner, remove the partner, and measure the 9  new lifetime reproductive success, LRSP. We can then replace every individual in the 10  focal population with a genotype adapted to the absence of the partner, and measure 11  the new lifetime reproductive success, LRSU. The evolved dependence is LRSU – 12  LRSP. 13  Ultimate response: Difference in performance before and after “long-term” removal 14  (or addition) of a partner species, allowing for adaptation to take place. Performance 15  of a genotype (or group thereof) adapted to the presence of the partner is measured in 16  the presence of the partner, and compared to the performance of a genotype (or group 17  thereof) adapted to the absence of the partner measured in the absence of the partner. 18  Measurement – If performance is measured as lifetime reproductive success, the focal 19  species’ density in the presence and absence of its partner must be kept the same. We 20  can then consider the focal population with its partner, with LRS = 1; remove the 21  partner and replace every individual in the focal population with a genotype adapted 22  to the absence of the partner, and measure the new lifetime reproductive success, 23  LRSU. The ultimate response to removal is LRSU – 1. 24  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    35 Ultimate mutualism: Interspecific interaction in which each partner species could 1  never have performed as well without the other, even if it was adapted to the absence 2  of the partner. In other words, an ultimate mutulaism is characterised by negative 3  ultimate responses of each species to the removal of the other species. 4  Mutualistic evolution: Evolution of a trait that is costly to the bearer but beneficial to 5  its partner in a proximate mutualism (investment in a partner sensu Connor, 1995). 6  Note that adaptation to the partner does not necessarily imply mutualistic evolution; 7  for example, there can be evolution of traits that allow to better exploit the partner. 8  Obligate mutualism: Interaction in which the removal of the partner results in death 9  or complete loss of reproduction in the focal species. The focal species has therefore a 10  proximate benefit from the interaction, as its proximate response to partner removal is 11  maximally negative. In many cases, the ultimate response to partner removal cannot 12  be measured in obligate mutualisms. (Antonym: facultative mutualism). 13  Conditional mutualism: Interspecific interaction that is mutualistic (proximately or 14  ultimately) only under specific environmental conditions (Bronstein, 1994a). 15  de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    36 Figure 1.  Performance of a genotype adapted to the absence of its partner (left 1  column), a genotype adapted to the presence of its partner (right column), both in the 2  presence of the partner (upper row), and in the absence of its partner (lower row). 3  Differences between these four performances measure the responses discussed in the 4  text. The proximate response of the organism to partner removal is measured for 5  individual genotypes, as FGa/p – FGa/a for the genotype adapted to the partner, and as 6  FGp/p – FGp/a for the genotype adapted to the absence of the partner. The ultimate 7  response of the organism to partner removal is measured as FGp/p – FGa/a, i.e., as the 8  difference between the performance in the presence of the partner of a genotype that 9  evolved with the partner and the performance in the absence of the partner of a 10  genotype that evolved without the partner. Evolved dependence is measured as the 11  difference between the performance without the partner of a genotype that evolved 12  without the partner and the performance without the partner of a genotype that 13  evolved with the partner, FGa/a – FGp/a. Note that the ultimate response of a genotype 14  adapted to the partner equals its proximate response minus the evolved dependence. 15    de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann    37   Partner present Partner absent Genotype Ga, adapted to absence of partner: Genotype Gp, adapted to presence of partner: FGa/a FGa/p FGp/p FGp/a Evolved dependence Proximate response Proximate response Ult ima te r esp ons e         Figure 1 de Mazancourt, Loreau and Dieckmann

title: The Emergence of Reciprocally Beneficial Cooperation
authors: BERALDO, SERGIO, Sugden R.
abstract: This paper offers a new and robust model of the emergence and persistence of cooperation. In the model, interactions are anonymous, the population is well-mixed, and the evolutionary process selects strategies according to material payoffs. The cooperation problem is modelled as a game similar to Prisoner’s Dilemma, but there is an outside option of nonparticipation and the payoff to mutual cooperation is stochastic; with positive probability, this payoff exceeds that from cheating against a cooperator. Under mild conditions, mutually beneficial cooperation occurs in equilibrium. This is possible because the non-participation option holds down the equilibrium frequency of cheating
topics: Cooperation, voluntary participation, random payoffs.

title: Mutualisms in a changing world: an evolutionary perspective.
authors: Kiers, E.T., Palmer, T.M., Ives, A.I., Bruno, J., Bronstein, J.L.
abstract: There is growing concern that rapid environmental degradation threatens mutualistic interactions. Because mutualisms can bind species to a common fate, mutualism breakdown has the potential to expand and accelerate effects of global change on biodiversity loss and ecosystem disruption. The current focus on the ecological dynamics of mutualism under global change has skirted fundamental evolutionary issues. Here, we develop an evolutionary perspective on mutualism breakdown to complement the ecological perspective, by focusing on three processes: (1) shifts from mutualism to antagonism, (2) switches to novel partners and (3) mutualism abandonment. We then identify the evolutionary factors that may make particular classes of mutualisms especially susceptible or resistant to breakdown and discuss how communities harbouring mutualisms may be affected by these evolutionary responses. We propose a template for evolutionary research on mutualism resilience and identify conservation approaches that may help conserve targeted mutualisms in the face of environmental change. © 2010 Blackwell Publishing Ltd/CNRS

title: The emergence of cooperation by evolutionary generalization
authors: Geoffroy, F., André, J.
abstract: In principle, any cooperative behaviour can be evolutionarily stable as long as it is incentivized by a reward from the beneficiary, a mechanism that has been called reciprocal cooperation. However, what makes this mechanism so powerful also has an evolutionary downside. Reciprocal cooperation faces a chicken-and-egg problem of the same kind as communication: it requires two functions to evolve at the same time—cooperation and response to cooperation. As a result, it can only emerge if one side first evolves for another reason, and is then recycled into a reciprocal function. Developing an evolutionary model in which we make use of machine learning techniques, we show that this occurs if the fact to cooperate and reward others’ cooperation become general abilities that extend beyond the set of contexts for which they have initially been selected. Drawing on an evolutionary analogy with the concept of generalization, we identify the conditions necessary for this to happen. This allows us to understand the peculiar distribution of reciprocal cooperation in the wild, virtually absent in most species—or limited to situations where individuals have partially overlapping interests, but pervasive in the human species

title: Evolution of indirect reciprocity by image scoring
authors: Nowak, M.A., Sigmund, K.
abstract: Darwinian evolution has to provide an explanation for cooperative behaviour. Theories of cooperation are based on kin selection (dependent on genetic relatedness) group selection and reciprocal altruism. The idea of reciprocal altruism usually involves direct reciprocity: repeated encounters between the same individuals allow for the return of an altruistic act by the recipient. Here we present a new theoretical framework, which is based on indirect reciprocity and does not require the same two individuals ever to meet again. Individual selection can nevertheless favour cooperative strategies directed towards recipients that have helped others in the past. Cooperation pays because it confers the image of a valuable community member to the cooperating individual. We present computer simulations and analytic models that specify the conditions required for evolutionary stability of indirect reciprocity. We show that the probability of knowing the 'image' of the recipient must exceed the cost-to-benefit ratio of the altruistic act. We propose that the emergence of indirect reciprocity was a decisive step for the evolution of human societies

title: Cooperation in partnerships: the role of breakups and reputation
authors: Bayer, R.
abstract: We investigate experimentally if endogenous partnership formation improves efficiency in social dilemmas. Subjects play multiple two-player public-goods games, where they can break up with their partner periodically. A stable-marriage mechanism based on rankings provided by singles determines the new matches. We vary the information subjects have on possible matches and whether staying in a partnership leads to a cost or a bonus. We find that endogenous group formation can increase efficiency. Both the provision of contribution history and bonuses have positive effects. At least one of these factors is required for efficiency improvements. The presence of both leads to the best results. (JEL: D03, D83, H41)Ralph-C. Baye
journals: Journal of Institutional and Theoretical Economics JITE

title: Support for the habitat amount hypothesis from a global synthesis of species density studies
authors: Watling, James I., Arroyo-Rodríguez, Victor, Pfeifer, Marion, Baeten, Lander, Banks-Leite, Cristina, Cisneros, Laura M., Fang, Rebecca, Hamel-Leigue, A. Caroli, Lachat, Thibault, Leal, Inara R., Lens, Luc, Possingham, Hugh P., Raheem, Dinarzarde C., Ribeiro, Danilo B., Slade, Eleanor M., Urbina-Cardona, J. Nicolas, Wood, Eric M., Fahrig, Lenore
abstract: Decades of research suggest that species richness depends on spatial characteristics of habitat patches, especially their size and isolation. In contrast, the habitat amount hypothesis predicts that (1) species richness in plots of fixed size (species density) is more strongly and positively related to the amount of habitat around the plot than to patch size or isolation; (2) habitat amount better predicts species density than patch size and isolation combined, (3) there is no effect of habitat fragmentation per se on species density and (4) patch size and isolation effects do not become stronger with declining habitat amount. Data on eight taxonomic groups from 35 studies around the world support these predictions. Conserving species density requires minimising habitat loss, irrespective of the configuration of the patches in which that habitat is contained
topics: Forest loss, Habitat amount, Patch size, Sampling effect, 1105 Ecology, Evolution, Behavior and Systematics

authors: Fahrig, L. (Lenore)
abstract: I challenge (1) the assumption that habitat patches are natural units of measurement for species richness, and (2) the assumption of distinct effects of habitat patch size and isolation on species richness. I propose a simpler view of the relationship between habitat distribution and species richness, the 'habitat amount hypot
topics: Edge effect, Habitat fragmentation, Habitat loss, Local landscape, Local patch, Matrix quality, Nested subsets, SLOSS, Species accumulation curve, Species-area relationship

title: SYNTHESIS Rethinking patch size and isolation effects: the habitat amount hypothesis
authors: Lenore Fahrig
abstract: I challenge (1) the assumption that habitat patches are natural units of mea-surement for species richness, and (2) the assumption of distinct effects of hab-itat patch size and isolation on species richness. I propose a simpler view of the relationship between habitat distribution and species richness, the ‘habitat amount hypothesis’, and I suggest ways of testing it. The habitat amount hypothesis posits that, for habitat patches in a matrix of non-habitat, the patch size effect and the patch isolation effect are driven mainly by a single underly-ing process, the sample area effect. The hypothesis predicts that species richness in equal-sized sample sites should increase with the total amount of habitat in the ‘local landscape ’ of the sample site, where the local landscape is the area within an appropriate distance of the sample site. It also predicts that species richness in a sample site is independent of the area of the particular patch in which the sample site is located (its ‘local patch’), except insofar as the area of that patch contributes to the amount of habitat in the local landscape of th
topics: habitat fragmentation, habitat loss, l

title: Data from: Experimental evidence does not support the Habitat Amount Hypothesis
authors: Haddad, Nick M., Gonzalez, Andrew, Brudvig, Lars A., Burt, Melissa A., Levey, Douglas J., Damschen, Ellen I.
abstract: For a half century, habitat configuration – the arrangement of habitat patches within a landscape – has been central to theories of landscape ecology, population dynamics, and community assembly, in addition to conservation strategies. A recent hypothesis advanced by Fahrig (2013) would, if supported, greatly diminish the relevance of habitat configuration as a predictor of diversity. The Habitat Amount Hypothesis posits that the sample area effect overrides patch size and patch isolation effects of habitat fragmentation on species richness. It predicts that the amount of habitat in a local landscape, regardless of configuration, is the main landscape-level determinant of species richness. If habitat amount is indeed the major, landscape-level driver of species richness, the slopes of the species–area relationship (SAR) for otherwise similar fragmented and unfragmented landscapes should be indistinguishable. We tested the Habitat Amount Hypothesis with data from two replicated and controlled habitat fragmentation experiments that disentangle the effects of habitat amount and configuration. One experiment provided time-series data on plant species richness and the other on micro-arthropod species richness. We found that, relative to less fragmented habitats, the SARs for fragmented habitats have significantly higher slopes and that the magnitude of the difference in slopes increased over time. Relatively more species were lost in smaller areas when fragments were more isolated. In both experiments, the proportion of species lost due to increased habitat fragmentation was nearly identical to the proportion lost due to reduced habitat amount. Our results provide a direct and experimentally derived refutation of the Habitat Amount Hypothesis, supporting the long-held view that in addition to area, patch isolation and configuration are important determinants of species richness. Differences in species richness between fragmented and non-fragmented habitats increase over time, demonstrating that long-term studies are needed to understand the effects of fragmentation, above and beyond the amount of habitat lost
subjects: Life sciences, medicine and health care
topics: Life sciences, medicine and health care

title: Can habitat selection predict abundance?
authors: Boyce, Mark S., Johnson, Chris J., Merrill, E.H., Nielsen, Scott E., Solberg, Erling Johan, Van Moorter, Bram
abstract: . Habitats have substantial inﬂuence on the distribut ion and abundance of animals. Ani-  mals’ selective mo vement yields their habitat use. Animals generally are more abundant in  habitats that are selected most strongly.  2. Models of habitat selection can be used to distribute animals on the landscape or their  distribution can be modelled based on data of habitat use, occupancy, intensity of use or  counts of animals. When the population is at carrying capacity or in an ideal-free distri-  bution, habitat selection and related metrics of habitat use can be used to estimate abun-  dance.  3. If the population is not at equilibrium, models have the ﬂexibility to incorporate density  into models of habitat selection; but abundance might be inﬂuenced by factors inﬂuencing ﬁt-  ness that are not directly related to habitat thereby compromising the use of habitat-based  models for predicting population size.  4. Scale and domain of the sampling fram e, both in time and space, are crucial consider-  ations limiting application of these models. Ultimately, identifying reliable models for predict-  ing abundance from habitat data requires an understanding of the mechanisms underlying  population regulation and limitation.  animal movement, occupancy, population estimation, population size, presence-  only data, resource selection function
topics: VDP::Matematikk og Naturvitenskap: 400::Zoologiske og botaniske fag: 480

title: Using relative-capacity to measure habitat suitability
authors: Hirzel, A.H.
abstract: Habitat suitability (HS) modeling relates a species' potential presence/absence to a set of environmental variables. Because of stochastic or demographic population fluctuations, relating abundance to environment is difficult and generally requires,, time-series of population-density data. Here, I propose an approach to compute relative capacity of a set of habitat classes. I defined relative capacity of a habitat class as being proportional to its carrying capacity, and replaced time-series of density measures with spatial replicates. A hypothetical environment was first divided into several habitat classes and population densities were measured in a sample of these habitats. Three methods of computing relative capacity were compared: (1) maximum density per habitat class, (2) coefficients of a Generalized Linear Model (GLM) of the habitat densities, and (3) slopes of isodars computed for all pairs of habitat classes. Accuracy of these methods was evaluated using spatially-explicit demographic Simulations. I investigated biological assumptions (species' sensitivity, reactivity and selectivity, regional stochasticity) and sampling design (sample size, distance between pairs of habitat classes. number of habitat classes, uncertainty over abundance). GLM and maximum-density methods provided accurate results when at least five site-pairs were available. Isodars outperformed other methods in landscapes with many habitat classes, but are best suited to large or noise-free data sets. Optimal performance was reached with more than 50 site-pairs and five habitat classes
topics: habitat suitability;  ideal free distribution;  isodar theory;  population dynamics;  simulated data;  spatial ecology;  virtual species

title: Ecology2050 Grassland Dataset #1
authors: Kurt Ramos (3128523)
abstract:
Hypothesis: It is predicted that the more abundance of species in a square-meter area, the less rich that area will be, due to it being a hotspot for certain species of plants to thrive and outcompete other plant species.

Predictions: The higher the number of individual plants in a square-meter area, the less rich in plant species that area will be. The more abundant a species is, the higher the % of the area it will cover, and the less grass will be present.   

A one meter-square quadrat was laid down on a grassland. An estimate by eye and calculations of the number of individual plants, the number of different species of plants, the % of plant cover, and the % of grass cover were each taken in that square-meter area.

The data was collected in the Danby Grassland, an open field, on a sunny late afternoon with a light breeze. There were no roads in the immediate area and was located next to a woodlot.
topics: Plant Biology, Community Ecology (excl. Invasive Species Ecology), York Univesity, Ecology, LIC0302, Grassland, Plants

title: Habitat Size Mediates the Effects of Environmental Factors on Species Richness
authors: Schuler, Matthew Scott
abstract: The Species Area Relationship (SAR) is one of the oldest and most fundamental patterns in ecology. Researchers have long known that a larger habitat will support more species than a smaller habitat. In the early 20th century, a predictive mathematical model was developed giving researchers an opportunity to understand the consequences of habitat loss for patterns of species richness and diversity. Species richness refers to the number of species observed within a given area. Related to species richness, species diversity is any statistical metric that allows researchers to compare species richness values measured across habitats that have varying probabilities of sampling individuals of the species present. Researchers have used the SAR model to understand the number of species that could be supported by a given amount of habitat, but have also used the SAR to compare the number of species supported by different habitats, to into infer important environmental factors that lead to differences in species richness among habitats. Ecologists have given great attention to studying the roles that these environmental factors play in determining how many species a given habitat will support. Yet, very little consideration has been given to the way in which habitat size alters the effects of those environmental factors on species richness patterns. This dissertation explores the influences that habitat size has on environmental factors that have been proposed as mechanisms that increase or maintain species richness in local habitats. I present three chapters each describing the findings of experiments that explored the interplay between habitat size and three commonly invoked mechanisms that affect local species richness: energy, species dispersal, and habitat heterogeneity. In Chapter 1, I present an experimental test of the species-energy-area relationship, where energy and area are predicted to interact in a positive way to increase the total number of species in a habitat. While much attention has been given to the interaction between habitat size and energy, researchers have failed to recognize that energy input may not be directly acting as a mechanism increasing species richness, but instead increasing the density of individuals, which increases the likelihood of detecting species in high-energy habitats. The 2nd chapter addresses the way in which habitat area alters the importance of dispersal for maintaining species richness in habitats, where small habitats are predicted to benefit more from dispersal than large habitats. Despite classical models in ecology predicting that species dispersal should be most important in small habitats, no conclusive experimental evidence exists showing that habitat size alters the importance of dispersal on species richness in local communities. Finally, in the 3rd chapter I present data from an experiment showing how the importance of habitat heterogeneity depends on habitat size and the aggregation of species among habitats. Habitat heterogeneity has been implicated as one of the most important mechanisms required to increase and maintain species richness in local communities. However, a meta-analysis of heterogeneity experiments revealed that experimental evidence is inconclusive, because many researchers have found positive and negative relationships between habitat heterogeneity and species richness. Additionally, the Area-Heterogeneity-Trade-Off (AHTO) model, developed to predict the relationship between habitat heterogeneity and species richness, has proven to be difficult to test in natural environments, due to the correlation of alternative environmental parameters with habitat heterogeneity. The results of this experiment support the main predictions of the AHTO, but show that the patterns predicted by the model can arise from alternative mechanisms than what the model predicts. The results from the experiments presented within this dissertation advance ecologists\u27 understanding of how environmental variables that are thought to drive patterns of species richness are mediated by the size of the habitat being studied. Furthermore, the results of these experiments add to a longstanding debate in ecology over the importance of habitat size in maintaining species richness. According to the SAR model, the reduction in size of a contiguous habitat will result in an immediate reduction in species richness. Some researchers have suggested, however, that the SAR model always under-predicts the loss of species richness as habitat size decreases. The research presented in this dissertation supports the conclusion that as habitat size decreases, species will be lost at a rate different from the prediction of the SAR model, due to the complex and non-linear relationships between habitat size and environmental factors like energy and heterogeneity that affect the number of species a local habitat could support
topics: Aquatic Ecology, Community Ecology, Diversity, Biology

title: USING RelatIve capacIty tO MeaSURe habItat SUItabIlIty
authors: Alexandre H. Hirzel
abstract: AbSTRACT Habitat suitability (HS) modeling relates a species ’ potential presence/ab-sence to a set of environmental variables. because of stochastic or demo-graphic population fluctuations, relating abundance to environment is difficult and generally requires time-series of population-density data. Here, I propose an approach to compute relative capacity of a set of habitat classes. I defined relative capacity of a habitat class as being proportional to its carrying capac-ity, and replaced time-series of density measures with spatial replicates. A hypothetical environment was first divided into several habitat classes and population densities were measured in a sample of these habitats. Three meth-ods of computing relative capacity were compared: (1) maximum density per habitat class, (2) coefficients of a Generalized Linear Model (GLM) of the habitat densities, and (3) slopes of isodars computed for all pairs of habitat classes. Accuracy of these methods was evaluated using spatially-explicit demographic simulations. I investigated biological assumptions (species’ sensitivity, reactivity and selectivity, regional stochasticity) and sampling de-sign (sample size, distance between pairs of habitat classes, number of habitat classes, uncertainty over abundance). GLM and maximum-density methods provided accurate results when at least five site-pairs were available. Isodars outperformed other methods in landscapes with many habitat classes, but are best suited to large or noise-free data sets. Optimal performance was reached with more than 50 site-pairs and five habitat classes
topics: habitat suitability, ideal free distribution, isodar theory, population dynamics

title: Predictions and retrodictions of the hierarchical representation of habitat in heterogeneous environments
authors: Kolasa, J., Allen, C.R., Sendzimir, J., Stow, C.A.
abstract: Interaction between habitat and species is central in ecology. Habitat structure may be conceived as being hierarchical, where larger, more diverse, portions or categories contain smaller, more homogeneous portions. When this conceptualization is combined with the observation that species have different abilities to  relate to portions of the habitat that differ in their characteristics, a number of known patterns can be derived and new patterns hypothesized. We propose a quantitative form of this habitat-species relationship by considering species abundance to be a function of habitat specialization, habitat fragmentation, amount of habitat, and adult body mass. The model reproduces and explains patterns such as variation in rank-abundance curves, greater variation and extinction probabilities of habitat specialists, discontinuities in traits (abundance, ecological range, pattern of variation, body size) among species sharing a community or area, and triangular distribution of body sizes, among others. The model has affinities to Holling's textural discontinuity hypothesis and metacommunity theory but  differs from both by offering a more general perspective. In support of the model, we illustrate its general potential to capture and explain several empirical observations that historically have been treated independently

title: Habitat amount, not habitat configuration, best predicts population genetic structure in fragmented landscapes
authors: Jackson, N.D. (Nathan D.), Fahrig, L. (Lenore)
abstract: Context: Landscape structure shapes the genetic structure of populations by delimiting spatial patterns of dispersal and reproduction across generations. Thus, descriptions of human-altered landscapes can be used to predict demographic and evolutionary outcomes of populations. Effectively measuring landscape structure to predict genetic structure requires that we understand the relative importance of distinct components of landscape structure (e.g., habitat amount and configuration) in creating spatial patterns of genetic variation. Objectives: We thus developed an individual-based simulation model to test predictions about the relative importance of habitat amount and configuration in producing genetic structure. We also investigated the independent relationships between components of landscape structure and the population dynamics that underlie genetic effects. Methods: We ran experiments in which we allowed gene flow and population size to vary as emergent outcomes of the interactions between hypothetical populations and heterogeneous landscapes. Results: We found that the amount of habitat in a landscape is a much better predictor of genetic structure than is habitat configuration. This pattern holds across a range of landscapes and dispersal distances and behaviors. When habitat is non-contiguous (i.e., fragmented), habitat amount mediates production of genetic differentiation by regulating both the size and isolation of habitat patches, which in turn regulate population size and gene flow. Conclusions: These results suggest that habitat amount, a simple measure that is easy to calculate, may often be the best metric for predicting population genetic structure and that when possible, measures of habitat amount and population size should be incorporated into landscape genetic studies
topics: Connectivity, Conservation genetics, Habitat fragmentation, Habitat loss, Individual-based model, Landscape metric
